summary: This is a Law360 White Collar newsletter from December 5, 2018, summarizing multiple legal news stories. One article reports that Jeffrey Epstein settled a dispute with the attorney for his victims on the eve of a trial, thereby avoiding victim testimony. The newsletter also covers other unrelated white-collar crime stories.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as a convicted billionaire sex offender who settled a dispute with his victims' attorney to avoid a trial where the women would have testified.

persons.name: Allison Aytes
persons.context: Former FDIC staffer accused by federal prosecutors of copying secret regulatory records for job interviews, while her defense claims it was accidental.

persons.name: Billy Walters
persons.context: Had $8.89 million in restitution for insider trading vacated and remanded by the Second Circuit.

persons.name: Michael Flynn
persons.context: Pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI; special counsel Robert Mueller noted he provided 'firsthand information' about Trump team-Russia contacts and argued for leniency.

persons.name: Robert Mueller
persons.context: Argued for lenient sentencing for Michael Flynn based on his cooperation in the Russia investigation.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of his team's contacts with Russian officials, as investigated by Robert Mueller.

persons.name: Salvatore Colonna
persons.context: Sentenced to 6.5 years for a $16 million precious metals and securities fraud scheme.

persons.name: Haena Park
persons.context: Her affiliated investment firms were ordered to pay $22.9 million in restitution for defrauding friends and family.

persons.name: Rod Rosenstein
persons.context: Announced changes to DOJ policy on cooperation credit for companies in criminal and civil cases.

persons.name: Scottie Pippen
persons.context: Sued a South Florida attorney-comedian and her husband for trashing his mansion.

connections.description: Epstein settled a dispute with the attorney representing his victims, avoiding a trial.
Mueller, as special counsel, was prosecuting Flynn and argued for leniency based on his cooperation.
Flynn was Trump's national security adviser and provided information about contacts between Trump's team and Russian officials.

events.title: Epstein Settles Victim Lawsuit
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein settled a dispute with the attorney for his teenage victims, avoiding a trial that was scheduled to feature testimony from the women.

events.title: Second Circuit Vacates Restitution for Billy Walters
events.description: A Second Circuit panel vacated and remanded $8.89 million in restitution ordered against professional gambler Billy Walters for insider trading.

events.title: Mueller Files Sentencing Memo for Michael Flynn
events.description: Special Counsel Robert Mueller filed a memo stating Michael Flynn provided 'firsthand information' and should receive lenient sentencing for lying to the FBI.

events.title: Trial of Allison Aytes Begins
events.description: Opening statements were given in the trial of ex-FDIC employee Allison Aytes, accused of taking secret bank regulatory records.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein settled a legal dispute with his victims' attorney on December 4, 2018, avoiding a trial where his victims were scheduled to testify.
The settlement prevented public testimony from Epstein's teenage victims about the abuse allegations.
The document is a legal industry newsletter showing the Epstein case was among other major white-collar crime news at the time.
The newsletter references Epstein's status as a 'convicted billionaire sex offender'.
The settlement occurred on the eve of the trial, indicating a strategic legal move to prevent victim testimony from becoming part of the public record.
